definitions.definition: able to make sensible decisions and give good advice because of the experience and knowledge that you have

examples.text: a **wise man**
I'm **older and wiser** after ten years in the business.
He played the role of the wise old man.
He was known to be a wise and gentle ruler.
He was too wise and experienced to try to escape.

definitions.sensetop: wise to do somethingit is wise (of somebody) to do something

examples.text: a wise decision/move/choice/investment
These are wise words indeed.
The wisest course of action is just to say nothing.
I was grateful for her wise counsel.
You would be wise to steer clear of the cheapest local wines.
He was wise to consider his future when he was working there.
It was very wise to leave when you did.
examples.contextForm: it is wise (of somebody) to do something

examples.text: It was wise of her to ask for a lawyer to be present.
It was very wise of you to leave when you did.
Locking your car doors is always a wise precaution.
It was not considered wise to move her to another hospital.

definitions.definition: to not understand something, even after it has been explained to you

examples.text: I've read the instructions, but I'm still none the wiser.

definitions.definition: to not know or find out about something bad that somebody has done

examples.text: If you put the money back, no one will be any the wiser.

definitions.definition: to understand something, or realize what you should have done, only after something has happened

examples.text: Anyone can be wise after the event.

definitions.definition: to become aware that somebody is being dishonest

examples.text: He thought he could fool me but I got wise to him.
This entertainer can crack wise with the best of them.

wordOrigin: Old English wīs, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wijs and German weise.
